_comment: Default mob head type registry for the Civil mod.
Modpack authors can add custom JSON files in
data/<namespace>/civil_heads/ to register new head types.
skull_type: must match SkullBlock.SkullType.toString() for vanilla,
or a custom string for modded heads.
entity_type: the mob this head attracts/converts to.
enabled: master switch (default true). If false, this head type is
completely invisible to all gameplay systems — suppress,
nearby bypass, and conversion are all disabled.
convert: whether this head participates in the conversion pool
(default true). A head with convert=false still counts
toward nearby head count and suppress range, but will
never be a conversion target.
Spawn behavior:
1-2 nearby heads: bypass civilization suppression (extra spawns),
but NO conversion.
3-10 heads: conversion probability scales linearly
Conversion target is weighted by placed head proportions.
Loading order: files are loaded alphabetically per namespace.
Later entries with the same skull_type override earlier ones
(full replacement — re-specify all fields you need).
Tip: to disable a specific head type incrementally, override it
with 'enabled': false. Example for a modpack that wants zombie
heads to be purely decorative:
{ "skull_type": "ZOMBIE", "enabled": false }
Set 'replace': true to clear ALL previously loaded head types
(useful for modpacks that want a complete custom table).
--- Mod compatibility ---
If a mod adds new skull types via custom AbstractSkullBlock
subclasses (with custom SkullType enums), you can register
them here by adding entries with the matching skull_type string.
Example for a mod that adds a Blaze head with type 'BLAZE':
{ "skull_type": "BLAZE", "entity_type": "minecraft:blaze" }
Note: mods that use PLAYER heads with custom textures (such as
All The Heads, Just Mob Heads) are NOT supported — our system
sees them all as skull_type 'PLAYER' and cannot distinguish
which mob they represent. Only mods using distinct SkullType
values are automatically compatible.
